sections.title: ðŸ“š Other ways to indicate the past.

content.introduction: Here's how to conjugate verbs in past tense using other past tense markers.
rows: The day before yesterday (or two days ago)
I was sick two days ago
I have just come from being sick (but I no longer am)

dialogue.speaker: Akinyi
dialogue.literal: You want + to do + what + with it?
dialogue.english: What do you want to do with it?

dialogue.speaker: Yambo
dialogue.literal: I come from + I divided it + twice.
dialogue.english: I have just come from dividing it in two.

dialogue.speaker: Yambo
dialogue.dholuo: Amiyo nyara nus, to wouda be amiyo nus
dialogue.literal: I give + my daughter + half, + and + my son + also + I give + half
dialogue.english: I will give my daughter half, and my son also half

words.notes: Derived from the word 'ng'iewo' which means 'to buy'
This is a loan word from the kiswahili word 'nusu' which means 'half'.
Derived from the verb 'pogo' which means 'to divide'.

pronunciation.tips: Uses the 'ng' sound at the end of the english word 'sing'.

exercises.question: Which of the following is the odd one out?
exercises.explanation: It's the only one in the present tense.

exercises.question: What does 'A amosogi' mean?
options: I have just come from greeting them
They have just come from greeting me
exercises.explanation: 'A' means 'to come from'. Taken together, 'A amosogi' means 'I have just come from greeting them'.
